standard.name: Achawa language
standard.notes: Arawakan language spoken in Meta Department of Colombia, closely related to Piapoco

standard.name: Acheron language
standard.notes: Niger-Congo language of the Talodi family, spoken in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan

standard.name: Adnyamathanha language
standard.notes: Spoken in Flinders Ranges, South Australia. Also known as yura ngarwala

standard.name: Afitti language
standard.notes: Nilo-Saharan language spoken in North Kordofan, Sudan. Most speakers are bilingual in Arabic

standard.name: Ainbai language
standard.notes: Torricelli language spoken in Sandaun Province, Papua New Guinea

standard.name: Ak language
standard.notes: Sepik language spoken in Sandaun Province, Papua New Guinea

standard.name: Arawum language
standard.notes: A Croisilles language spoken in Madang Province, Papua New Guinea

standard.name: Ari language (New Guinea)
standard.notes: Trans-New Guinea language spoken in Morobe Province, Papua New Guinea

standard.name: Asumbuo language
standard.notes: A language isolate spoken in Sandaun Province, Papua New Guinea

standard.name: Atong language (Sino-Tibetan)
standard.notes: Sino-Tibetan language spoken in Bangladesh and Meghalaya, India

standard.name: Baraba dialect
standard.notes: Siberian Tatar dialect spoken in the Baraba steppe of Siberia, Russia

standard.name: Bepour language
standard.notes: Trans–New Guinea language spoken in Madang Province, Papua New Guinea

standard.name: Breton language
standard.notes: Celtic language of Brittany, France. Declined from over 1 million speakers in 1950

standard.name: Burate language
standard.notes: Geelvink Bay language spoken in Papua, Indonesia

standard.name: Burgundian language (Oïl)
standard.notes: A Romance language of the Oïl family spoken in Burgundy, France

standard.name: Cofán language
standard.notes: A language isolate spoken in Ecuador and Colombia

standard.name: Dair language
standard.notes: Nubian language spoken in the Nuba Mountains of Kordofan, Sudan

standard.name: Djabugay language
standard.notes: An Australian Aboriginal language, the traditional language of the Djabugay people of Queensland. Currently undergoing revival.

standard.name: Domari language
standard.notes: Indo-Aryan language spoken by the Dom people across the Middle East and North Africa

standard.name: Dyirbal language
standard.notes: Australian Aboriginal language from Queensland. Last fluent speaker died in 2011, but some speakers remain

standard.name: El Hugeirat language
standard.notes: A Daju language spoken in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan

standard.name: Even language
standard.notes: Tungusic language spoken in Siberia, Russia

standard.name: Evenki language
standard.notes: Tungusic language spoken across Siberia and northern China

standard.name: Gallo language
standard.notes: A Romance language of the Oïl family spoken in Upper Brittany, France. Lacks its own ISO 639-3 code.

standard.name: Gija language
standard.notes: An Australian Aboriginal language spoken in the East Kimberley region of Western Australia

standard.name: Trans-Zab Jewish Neo-Aramaic
standard.notes: Also known as Lishan Didan. A Neo-Aramaic dialect originally spoken by Jews in Iranian Azerbaijan.

standard.name: Ili Turki language
standard.notes: A Turkic language spoken in the Ili Kazakh Autonomous Prefecture in Xinjiang, China

standard.name: Ingrian language
standard.notes: A Finnic language spoken by the Izhorians of Ingria, Russia

standard.name: Inter-Zab Jewish Neo-Aramaic
standard.notes: A Neo-Aramaic dialect formerly spoken by Jews in Sanandaj, Iran. Now considered extinct.

standard.name: Istro-Romanian language
standard.notes: A Balkan Romance language spoken in a few villages in Istria, Croatia

standard.name: Jewish Neo-Aramaic dialect of Zakho
standard.notes: A dialect of Northeastern Neo-Aramaic originally spoken by Jews in Zakho, Iraq. Considered extinct.

standard.name: Judaeo-Spanish
standard.notes: Also known as Ladino. Romance language derived from Old Spanish, now spoken mainly in Israel and Turkey

standard.name: Judeo-Berber language
standard.notes: A variety of Berber languages spoken by Jewish communities in Morocco

standard.name: Judeo-Tunisian Arabic
standard.notes: A variety of Tunisian Arabic spoken by Jews in Tunisia

standard.name: Kalamang language
standard.notes: A Trans-New Guinea language spoken on the Karas Islands of Indonesia

standard.name: Kanga language
standard.notes: A Kadu language spoken in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan

standard.name: Kangjia language
standard.notes: A Mongolic language spoken in Qinghai Province, China

standard.name: Kapingamarangi language
standard.notes: A Polynesian language spoken on Kapingamarangi atoll, Federated States of Micronesia

standard.name: Keiga language
standard.notes: A Kadu language spoken in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan

standard.name: Ket language
standard.notes: Last surviving Yeniseian language of Siberia. Only a few dozen fluent speakers remain

standard.name: Kili language
standard.notes: A Tungusic language spoken in Khabarovsk Krai, Russia, and Heilongjiang, China

standard.name: Kofei language
standard.notes: A Geelvink Bay language spoken in Papua, Indonesia

standard.name: Koko-Bera language
standard.notes: An Australian Aboriginal language spoken on the Cape York Peninsula, Queensland

standard.name: Kosraean language
standard.notes: A Micronesian language spoken on the island of Kosrae, Federated States of Micronesia

standard.name: Kri language
standard.notes: A Trans–New Guinea language spoken in Morobe Province, Papua New Guinea

standard.name: Kristang language
standard.notes: A Portuguese-based creole spoken in Malacca, Malaysia, and Singapore

standard.name: Kugu Nganhcara language
standard.notes: An Australian Aboriginal language spoken on the Cape York Peninsula, Queensland

standard.name: Kunjen language
standard.notes: An Australian Aboriginal language spoken on the Cape York Peninsula, Queensland

standard.name: Kursav language
standard.notes: A Trans-New Guinea language spoken in Madang Province, Papua New Guinea

standard.name: Lafofa languages
standard.notes: A Niger-Congo language spoken in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan

standard.name: Logol language
standard.notes: A Niger-Congo language spoken in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan

standard.name: Malak-Malak language
standard.notes: An Australian Aboriginal language spoken in the Northern Territory of Australia

standard.name: Maliseet-Passamaquoddy language
standard.notes: An Algonquian language spoken by the Maliseet and Passamaquoddy peoples in Maine, USA and New Brunswick, Canada

standard.name: Mangareva language
standard.notes: A Polynesian language spoken on the Gambier Islands in French Polynesia

standard.name: Mores language
standard.notes: A Skou language spoken in Papua, Indonesia

standard.name: Namonuito language
standard.notes: A Micronesian language spoken on Namonuito Atoll, Chuuk State, Federated States of Micronesia

standard.name: Nauna language
standard.notes: An Oceanic language of Manus Province, Papua New Guinea

standard.name: Nauruan language
standard.notes: An Austronesian language and an official language of Nauru

standard.name: Neku language
standard.notes: An Austronesian language spoken in Morobe Province, Papua New Guinea

standard.name: Neme language
standard.notes: A Trans–New Guinea language spoken in Madang Province, Papua New Guinea

standard.name: Nete language
standard.notes: A Trans–New Guinea language spoken in Madang Province, Papua New Guinea

standard.name: Ngile language
standard.notes: A Surmic language spoken in South Sudan

standard.name: North Frisian language
standard.notes: West Germanic language spoken in North Frisia, Germany. Has 9-10 dialects divided between insular and mainland groups

standard.name: Oirat language
standard.notes: A Mongolic language spoken by the Oirats, primarily in Kalmykia, Russia

standard.name: Otomi language
standard.notes: An Oto-Pamean language spoken in the central Altiplano of Mexico

standard.name: Otoro language
standard.notes: A Niger-Congo language spoken in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan

standard.name: Pááfang language
standard.notes: A Micronesian language spoken in Chuuk State, Federated States of Micronesia

standard.name: Picard language
standard.notes: A Romance language of the Oïl family spoken in northern France and southern Belgium

standard.name: Pije language
standard.notes: An Oceanic language spoken in the North Province of New Caledonia

standard.name: Pingelapese language
standard.notes: A Micronesian language spoken on Pingelap atoll, Pohnpei State, Federated States of Micronesia

standard.name: Puluwat language
standard.notes: A Micronesian language spoken on Puluwat atoll, Chuuk State, Federated States of Micronesia

standard.name: Pwapwâ language
standard.notes: An Oceanic language spoken in the North Province of New Caledonia

standard.name: Rapa Nui language
standard.notes: Polynesian language of Easter Island (Chile)

standard.name: Rema language
standard.notes: A Trans–New Guinea language of Madang Province, Papua New Guinea. Considered extinct.

standard.name: Satawalese language
standard.notes: A Micronesian language spoken on Satawal island, Yap State, Federated States of Micronesia

standard.name: Shatt language
standard.notes: A Nilo-Saharan language spoken in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan

standard.name: Ske language
standard.notes: An Oceanic language spoken on Pentecost Island, Vanuatu

standard.name: Sonsorolese
standard.notes: A Micronesian language spoken in Sonsorol State, Palau

standard.name: Tagoi language
standard.notes: A Niger-Congo language spoken in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan

standard.name: Tambotalo language
standard.notes: A Trans-New Guinea language spoken in Madang Province, Papua New Guinea

standard.name: Tanimbili language
standard.notes: A Skou language spoken in Papua, Indonesia

standard.name: Temein language
standard.notes: A Nilo-Saharan language spoken in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan

standard.name: Tima language
standard.notes: A language isolate spoken in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan

standard.name: Tobati language
standard.notes: An Austronesian language spoken in Jayapura, Papua, Indonesia

standard.name: Tocho language
standard.notes: A Niger-Congo language spoken in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan

standard.name: Tokelauan language
standard.notes: Polynesian language of Tokelau

standard.name: Transylvanian Saxon dialect
standard.notes: A Moselle Franconian dialect of German spoken in Transylvania, Romania

standard.name: Tulishi language
standard.notes: A Kadu language spoken in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan

standard.name: Tumtum language
standard.notes: A Kadu language spoken in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan

standard.name: Ubi language
standard.notes: An Afro-Asiatic language of uncertain classification spoken in Chad

standard.name: Udi language
standard.notes: Northeast Caucasian language spoken in Azerbaijan and Georgia

standard.name: Ulithian language
standard.notes: A Micronesian language spoken on Ulithi Atoll, Yap State, Federated States of Micronesia

standard.name: Umpila language
standard.notes: An Australian Aboriginal language spoken on the Cape York Peninsula, Queensland

standard.name: Wa language
standard.notes: An Oceanic language spoken in West New Britain Province, Papua New Guinea

standard.name: Walser German
standard.notes: A Highest Alemannic German dialect spoken by the Walser people in the Alps

standard.name: Woleaian language
standard.notes: A Micronesian language spoken on Woleai Atoll, Yap State, Federated States of Micronesia

standard.name: Xibe language
standard.notes: Tungusic language spoken in Xinjiang, China

standard.name: Yimas language
standard.notes: Papuan language of Papua New Guinea

standard.name: Yugambeh–Bundjalung languages
standard.notes: A dialect chain of Australian Aboriginal languages spoken in New South Wales and Queensland

standard.name: Eastern Yugur language
standard.notes: A Mongolic language spoken by the Yugur people in Gansu, China

standard.name: Western Yugur language
standard.notes: A Turkic language spoken by the Yugur people in Gansu, China

standard.name: Zay
standard.notes: An Ethiopian Semitic language spoken in the vicinity of Lake Zway, Ethiopia
